bio: Usain Bolt, OJ, CD, MPN, AON, KST, SP, FRSA (born 21 August 1986) is a Jamaican retired Sprinter, track and field athlete. While in his prime, he was frequently called the fastest person ever timed. In 2013, he became the first athlete to win both the 100 meters and 200 meters at three separate Olympic Games and in 2016 the first to win both events at three consecutive Olympic Games. Along with his teammates, he also set the world record in the 4 × 100 meters relay at the 2015 IAAF World Relays. He is the only man to win Olympic 100 m and 200 m gold medals at three consecutive Olympics (2008, 2012 and 2016), and the first to with the World Championship 100 m trophy in 2009.He was the first to achieve a "double double" in sports, that is, to win consecutive 100 m and 200 m titles at consecutive Olympics and then subsequently to repeat the feat in consecutive World Championships (in 2013 and 2015).

bio: The Heiress (1947 play) is a play based on the 1875 novel Washington Square by Henry James that was the basis for an earlier film version. In her play, Ruth and Augustus Goetz adapted the plot as a modern Gothic parable set in an aristocratic 1850s world in New York City. The Heiress premiered on Broadway at the Booth Theater on March 1, 1947, directed by George Cukor from a set design by Jo Mielzinger. The play has been revived on Broadway twice, in 1976 and 2005, with both runs lasting half a year.

bio: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated science-fiction sitcom that premiered on December 2, 2013, on Cartoon Network's late-night programming block Adult Swim. The show follows the misadventures of alcoholic scientific genius Rick and his awkward grandson Morty, who split their time between domestic family life and interdimensional travel. Promotional material depicts adult swim as referring to both the more mature content of the animation block (as opposed to children's fare) and the duality of Morty's and Rick's familial, yet adversarial, bond.

bio: Geraldine Chaplin (born Geraldine Leonie Chaplin on July 31, 1944) is an English-born American actress who made her film debut in 1960. bio: The Reader (2008 film) is an English-language drama film directed by Stephen Daldry and written by David Hare. It is the film adaptation of the 1995 German novel of the same title by Bernhard Schlink, which is set in both Germany and the United States. It is about an affair between an older woman and a boy, seen from the perspectives of both the woman and the now-adult man. Ralph Fiennes and Kate Winslet star and the film is narrated by David Kross, who plays the boy. The film won Academy Awards for Best Actress (Kate Winslet), Best Supporting Actor (Michael Stuhlbarg), and Best Film Editing.[4][5] It was also nominated for Best Director, Best Picture and Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress (Katharina Schüttler).

bio: Emily Ratajkowski (born June 7, 1991) is an American model and actress. Known as Emrata, she rose to widespread prominence in 2013 after appearing in the music video for Robin Thicke's "Blurred Lines", which became the number one song of the year in several countries and was the longest running song of 2013 in the United Kingdom. In 2014, she appeared as the mistress of Ben Affleck's character in the film Gone Girl and played Andie in the film Sex & the City 2 (2010). In 2016, Ratajkowski played roles in the science fiction films We Are Your Friends and In Darkness, adapted from the eponymous novel, The Blunderer (film).

bio: The Bridges of Madison County (film) is a 1995 American romantic drama film based on the bestselling novel of the same name by Robert James Waller. The film was produced and directed by Clint Eastwood with the screenplay written by Richard LaGravenese; it stars Meryl Streep and Eastwood. It centers on an Italian war bride, Francesca Johnson (Streep), who lives her life mostly based on her husband's wishes and the local customs he brought her from Italy. She suddenly finds herself caught up in an intense affair with National Geographic photographer Robert Kincaid (Eastwood) when he comes to Madison County to photograph the famous local covered bridges...

bio: Anaconda (Nicki Minaj song) is a song performed by American recording artist Nicki Minaj from her third studio album The Pinkprint (2014). The song was released on August 4, 2014, as the third single from the album. The song, which was written and produced by Minaj in collaboration with its rappers, Lil Wayne, Jessie Reyez and 6ix, contains interpolations of "Get It", recorded by Redman, who appears on the original song. The official remix, released in September 2014, features singer Justin Bieber. Minaj was inspired by her experiences with "big booty mack[s]", and composed the song from a male perspective. Lyrically, "Anaconda" discusses the subject's large bottom.

bio: Tom Hiddleston (born 9 February 1981) is an English actor, director, writer and producer. At the beginning of his career, he appeared in West End theatre productions of Cymbeline (2007) and Ivanov (2008). He won the Laurence Olivier Award for Best Newcomer in a Play for his role in Cymbeline and was nominated for the same award for his role as Cassio in Othello in 2008. He came to wider public attention when cast as Loki in the film Thor (2011). In the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), this role has continued in Thor: The Dark World (2013), Thor: Ragnarok (2017), Avengers: Infinity War (2018) and Avengers: Endgame (2019). He also appeared in Steven Spielberg's biopic drama The War Horse (2011), and Woody Allen's romantic comedy Midnight in Paris (2011), receiving British Independent Film Award nominations for both.

bio: Baahubali: The Beginning, also known by the initialism BB1, is a 2015 Indian multilingual epic action-adventure film directed by S. S. Rajamouli. It was originally planned for release on 10 July 2015, but was postponed and released worldwide on 10 July 2015, coinciding with India's Independence Day. The film chronicles the story from the ancient Indian historical drama The Mahabharata, and is the first in the two-part fantasy films involving Mahishmati Kingdom. It is the most expensive Indian film made to date, and also the most expensive Indian film ever produced. Baahubali: The Beginning was a critical and commercial success, and was nominated for several Indian and international awards. It was screened as part of the inauguration of the 46th International Film Festival of India, earning a standing ovation at the end of the screening.

bio: Alive 2006/2007 is the eighth international and tenth overall live album by the American alternative metal band, Alice Cooper. bio: Harry Potter (film series) is an American-British film series based on the Harry Potter novels by author J. K. Rowling. The series is distributed by Warner Bros. and consists of eight fantasy films, beginning with Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001) and culminating with Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011). A spin-off prequel series will consist of three films, beginning with Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016).

bio: Muhammad Ali, born Cassius Marcellus Clay, Jr.; January 17, 1942–June 3, 2016, was an American professional boxer, activist and philanthropist. He is widely regarded as one of the most significant and celebrated sports figures of the 20th century and one of the greatest boxers of all time. He is the only three-time lineal World Heavyweight Champion; he won the National Boxing Association (NBA) and World Boxing Association (WBA) titles in 1964 and the World Boxing Council (WBC) title in 1967 from Sonny Liston. In 1974, Ali defeated George Foreman, who had been the heavyweight boxing champion of the world, to retake the title; he became the first boxer to be named Sportsman of the Year by Sports Illustrated magazine.[2]

bio: Cult film is a cinema genre that exists on the fringe of mainstream cinematic expression. Cult films are known for their transgression of social taboos and controversial subject matter. Often times they feature satirical or sarcastic portrayals of accepted moral values, an urban setting, technical or artistic innovation, or "any material that can be construed as taboo-breaking" such as nudity, profanity, drug use, or violence. The subject of the film is often an outcast or anti-hero rather than the more heroic characters prevalent in mainstream films as they do not abide by society's norms and common moral values.

bio: One More Light is the seventh studio album by American rock band Linkin Park. It was released on May 19, 2017, under Warner Bros. Records; this marks the band's first album not to be released under the Machine Shop Recordings label. The album is the last to feature the late vocalist Chester Bennington, who died less than one month after it was released. He was replaced by band member Mike Shinoda. The album is dedicated to Bennington and also pays tribute to those affected by suicide.

bio: Social justice is the proper functioning of the social institutions within a society that allow for everyone to have a fair share in that society and to maintain a fair degree of social coherence. A proper functioning of social institutions is that which ensures that opportunities for developing individuals, families, groups, and communities are readily available without barriers such as discrimination and/or poverty. The social justice framework involves the "distribution of resources (including income) produced by a society" and attempts to remedy inequalities that exist in such distributions.[1][2][3] Social justice may be sought "through a government-sponsored welfare state, or through private charitable efforts by individuals and organizations, or a combination of the two."[4] The philosopher John Rawls defines social justice as the “fair value” of the natural social assets that an individual holds and the social benefits which they realize. He defines the social assets, and the resulting social benefits, as the equal rights and liberties of citizens and the powers and responsibilities which they enjoy. For Rawls, social benefits are those societal benefits, such as health and longevity, which are produced by “social cooperation”, which he says may “raise the value of one’s position relative to everyone else.”[5][6] To ensure that social benefits are distributed fairly in society, Rawls suggests principles to inform the workings of “social institutions”,[7] which he defines as social organizations established by human beings to regulate collective action; including: “families, groups and communities, as well as national institutions and international institutions”. He argues that these principles form the basis of “social justice” and that when applied to the working of social institutions they will deliver social benefits to the members of society in proportion to their social assets.

bio: Ryan Gosling (born November 12, 1980) is a Canadian actor, director, writer, and musician. He began his career as a child star on the Disney Channel's Mickey Mouse Club (1993–95) and went on to appear in other family entertainment programs including Are You Afraid of the Dark? He starred in the Canadian series Breaker High as a role of "Dave Turner" in 1998. He came to the attention of a wide audience in 2004 with a leading role in the romantic drama The Notebook, for which he won several award nominations including the MTV Movie Award for Best Kiss and Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actor – Drama.

bio: The Catalyst is the third song from American band Linkin Park's fourth studio album, A Thousand Suns. It was released October 15, 2010 as single, along with a music video. The song is one of four songs on the album that Chester Bennington wrote completely by himself (the others being Burning in the Skies, Iridescent and When They Come for Me). The band have described the track as being about "future wars", with the lyrics "The Catalysts" being "people who start wars." The Catalyst has also been described as "one of the most anthemic moments in Linkin Park's discography", and has been noted for containing similarities with Eye of the Tiger by Survivor. After it was played, the album title was announced to fans.

bio: Blue-ringed octopus can be divided into four distinct life stages: egg, paralarval, alevin, and juvenile. This species is the only octopus that can survive out of the water for several weeks; however, in this environment the animal will not survive nearly as long as it does when in the water. Blue-ringed octopus spawn pelagically; this allows a greater distribution of eggs. Each female blue-ringed octopus will usually carry around 200,000 eggs around in its mantle.

bio: Singapore, officially the Republic of Singapore, is a sovereign city-state and island country in Southeast Asia. It lies off the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula and is 137 kilometres (85 mi) north of the equator. The country's territory consists of the lozenge-shaped main island, commonly referred to as Singapore Island in English and Pulau Ujong in Malay, and more than 60 significantly smaller islets. Singapore is separated from Peninsular Malaysia by the Straits of Johor to the north, and from Indonesia's Riau Islands by the Singapore Strait to the south. The country is highly urbanised, and little of the original landscape remains. The population density is 7,535 per square kilometre (19,498 per square mile) with almost 6 million people living in Singapore. Singapore was established as a British trading colony in 1819, after the signing of the Anglo-Dutch Treaty. Since independence, it has maintained a high level of economic growth.

bio: Three Days of the Condor is a 1975 American political espionage thriller film directed by Sydney Pollack and starring Robert Redford, Faye Dunaway, Cliff Robertson, and Max von Sydow. The screenplay, written by Lorenzo Semple Jr., is based on the 1974 novel Six Days of the Condor by James Grady. Several novelists and film critics consider the film to be a political allegory. The film was nominated for five Academy Awards and was nominated for the Grand Prix of the Belgian Film Critics Association.

bio: French Open is also commonly referred to in English as the French Championships and the Roland Garros, due to the venue's sponsorship by a sporting goods company. It is held over two weeks between late May and early June at the Stade Roland Garros in Paris. It is the largest of the four Grand Slam tournaments, the other three being the Australian Open, Wimbledon and the US Open. The French Open is the only Grand Slam tournament to have held tournaments during World Wars I and II.

bio: Eddie Vedder (born Edward Louis Severson III; 23 December 1964) is an American musician who is best known as the lead singer and one of three guitarists of the American rock band Pearl Jam. Vedder left the San Diego music scene to move to Seattle and join Pearl Jam in 1990. The band's 2006 album "Eddie Vedder" (also known as "Immortality) peaked at 75 on Billboard 200 and the compilation discs, TEN (2003) and The Very Best of Pearl Jam (2004), have both been certified gold.

bio: John Lennon (born John Winston Lennon, 9 October 1940 – 8 December 1980) was an English singer-songwriter, activist and one of the founding members, the most famous and influential lead vocalist of The Beatles. He was murdered aged 40 years. John Winston Ono Lennon, MBE (born John Winston Lennon; 9 October 1940 – 8 December 1980) was an English singer, songwriter and peace activist who gained worldwide fame as the founder, co-lead vocalist, and rhythm guitarist of New York City rock group The Beatles. He had been involved with rock music since the late 1950s, and for some 15 years had been the recipient of several prestigious music honours in the form of compositions, album sales and concert tours. Lennon's songs such as "Imagine", "Watching the Wheels" and "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)" have been covered by other musicians and have entered the cultural canon in the United Kingdom. He and Paul McCartney co-founded one of the most commercially successful bands in the history of popular music, The Beatles, and were one of the most well-recognized celebrities in the world. Between 1963 and 1975, Lennon released eight studio albums with The Beatles. In 1968, he co-founded with McCartney the Plastic Ono Band and with the Plastic Ono Band member, keyboardist and friend George Harrison he released the experimental album "Unfinished Music No. 1: Two Virgins" in 1968. That album, described as "the first LP of a full-fledged home production/performance" by Lennon, was the first of five experimental albums issued by the three together. Lennon disbanded the Plastic Ono Band in 1974 and embarked on a low-key solo career. He re-formed the group, with different members, in 1975. During his career, Lennon wrote, co-wrote, recorded and published many songs that have become classics

He is most widely known for playing Ross Geller in the popular American sitcom Friends, for which he received an Emmy Award. bio: Romelu Lukaku Mbombo (French pronunciation: ​[ʁɔ.mə.lu lukaku]; born 13 May 1993) is a Belgian professional footballer who plays as a striker for Premier League side Everton and captains the Belgium national team. Lukaku has been described as "immensely strong" and "tall, powerfully built and agile". In July 2014 he was named as the European Footballer of the Year by French magazine France Football, at 18 the third youngest to receive the accolade. He is also a two-time Belgian Professional Goalkeeper of the Year and a two-time winner of the Belgian Golden Shoe, and currently the competition's leading top scorer.

bio: David Beckham, OBE has won many trophies during his career for club, team and country. He has been called the "world's most famous man", and is one of the highest-paid sports personalities. During his 21-year-long career, for which he was captain for 11 years, Beckham played for Manchester United, Preston North End, Real Madrid, Milan, LA Galaxy, Paris St Germain, and the England national team, for which he holds the all-time appearance record outright at 115. He was part of the United team that won the 1998–99 Champions League and he also represented England at five FIFA World Cups and two UEFA European Championships, captaining the team three times. He announced his retirement from professional football on 18 May 2013, ending his 20-year career. Beckham is currently an ambassador for British brand H&M. In addition to his football and fashion work, he has established 7: The David Beckham UNICEF Fund, to help children around the world, and in 2014, he launched 7 Global Sports Innovation (GSi) to take sport and business innovation to a new level.

bio: Alien: Covenant is a 2017 American science fiction horror film directed by Ridley Scott, written by John Logan and Dante Harper, and produced by David Giler, Walter Hill, and Steve Wakha. It is a sequel to Prometheus (2012), the second installment in the Alien prequel series, and the sixth installment overall in the Alien film series, as well as the third directed by Scott. The film stars Michael Fassbender, Billy Crudup, Katherine Waterston, Danny McBride, Carmen Ejogo, and Demián Bichir. The story follows the crew of the colony ship Covenant who, while en route to a remote planet that could be an uncharted paradise, discover a dark, dangerous world when one of them ventures into an airlock without a spacesuit.

bio: Paul Bettany (born 27 May 1971) is an English actor. He first came to the attention of mainstream audiences when he appeared in the British films Gangster No. 1 (2000) and A Knight's Tale (2001). He has gone on to become known for his roles in films such as A Beautiful Mind (2001), Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003), The Da Vinci Code (2006), and Margin Call (2011), as well as the portrayal of both Charles Babbage and Bishop Eric in the period comedy film The Young Victoria (2009). Bettany is also known for his voice role as J.A.R.V.I.S. in the Marvel Cinematic Universe films Iron Man (2008), Iron Man 2 (2010), The Avengers (2012), Iron Man 3 (2013), Age of Ultron (2015), Captain America: Civil War (2016), Spider-Man: Homecoming (2017), Avengers: Infinity War (2018) and Avengers: Endgame (2019).

bio: Kim Basinger (born December 8, 1953) is an American actress and former fashion model. Initially an actress on television, Basinger came to prominence for her supporting role in The Natural (1984). She received critical praise and industry nominations including a Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress for her portrayal of Lynn Bracken in the 1991 neo-noir film L.A. Confidential (1997). Basinger is also well known for her role as Domino Petachi in the thriller The 9th Life of Louis Drax (2016). Basinger is a Golden Globe, SAG Award, and Oscar winning actress who has starred in such hits as Batman (1989), L.A. Confidential (1997), 8 Mile (2002) and No Mercy (1986).

bio: David Bowie (born 8 January 1947) is an English singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, record producer, arranger, painter, and actor. His career spans more than five decades, and he is widely regarded as an innovator, particularly for his work in the 1970s. He is known for his androgynous appearance, and during his Ziggy Stardust period, he became an icon for the LGBT community. Bowie's innovative work spans a variety of types of music, including rock, pop, electronic, dance, soul, hard rock, folk music, and jazz.

bio: Emmanuel Adebayor Togo is a Togolese professional footballer who plays as a forward for Turkish club İstanbul Başakşehir; he has also played professionally in France, Monaco, Spain, and the UK for teams including Metz, Marseille, Arsenal, Real Madrid, and Tottenham Hotspur. He has been a member of the Togo national team since 2002. Throughout his career, Adebayor has been praised for his work rate, close ball control and strength in the air, as well as his pace and ability to score acrobatic goals. Adebayor was brought up on the Togo team in the 2000 Summer Olympics, the 2001 FIFA Confederations Cup, the 2002 and 2006 Africa Cup of Nations. In the Confederations Cup, he was Togo's second top scorer in a surprising run up to their final game, the third place match. He scored goals against Poland and Brazil. Adebayor was then aged 21. Since arriving in Europe by signing for Football League France and then French Ligue 1 club Metz at age 22, the powerful striker has grown as a player. When joining Arsenal in 2006 for a club record £7 million (€10.05 million), he was a rising star of French club Monaco.

bio: IO Theater is a professional theater company established in 1998 by Andy Hinds and Mary Murfitt in their living room in Wicker Park at the corner of Milwaukee and Hoyne. Since its beginning, IO has produced more than 100 original productions with 500+ artists. The company moved out of its living room and into a rehearsal stage in December of 1998, and into its current space in late April 2000. IO’s first Mainstage Theater Season was established in 2003. As of 2012, the Mainstage Season includes two original plays and four re-interpretations of classics.

bio: Starbucks is an American coffee company and coffeehouse chain. Starbucks is the largest coffeehouse company in the world, with 23,768 stores in 66 countries, including 13,293 in the United States, 1,568 in Canada, 1,011 in Japan, 861 in Qatar, 835 in the United Kingdom and 137 in Singapore. Many coffee companies started during the 1970s. One of these (Peet's Coffee & Tea) was headquartered, like Starbucks, in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 1971, Starbucks was founded in Seattle, Washington as a local coffee bean retailer with a single store. The company's second location, opened in 1986 at Pier 70 in San Francisco, was housed within a warehouse built in 1850 that also hosted an art gallery and studios.

bio: River Phoenix (born River Jude Bottom; August 23, 1970 – October 31, 1993) was an American actor, musician, and activist. He was the younger brother of Rain Phoenix, Joaquin Phoenix, Liberty Phoenix and Summer Phoenix. bio: Bal Gangadhar Tilak (Gavandar Tuljapurkar/Marathi: Băḷ Gāṅgādhar Tīlak, 23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920) was an Indian nationalist, teacher, social reformer and independence activist. He was the first leader of the Indian Independence Movement; the founder of the Indian independence movement; popularized the Swadeshi movement; the leader of the Maratha people in Maharashtra and wrote the book 'The Arctic Home in the Vedas,' which inspired Indian nationalists including Batten Sundar Guru, Shyamji Krishnavarma and Bhikaji Cama. He advocated and worked for the Swadeshi policies in the Indian Independence Movement.

bio: Renaissance is a French neo-progressive rock group formed in 1978 by vocalist Annie Haslam, Michael Dunford on guitar and later bass, John Tout on keyboards, and Terence Sullivan on drums. In 1979 the group signed to EMI's label Harvest with Gerry Bron being their producer and arranged a contract with Caroline Records in the USA as well as other foreign labels (like Japan and Brazil). The members of the band were classically trained, and used the musical skills they had developed to play intricate, harmonized music.

bio: Agatha Christie was a British crime writer of novels, short stories, and plays published under her name. She also wrote romances as Mary Westmacott, but she is best remembered for her 80 detective novels. She is considered one of the greatest writers of mysteries. Her works have sold over a billion copies—a figure only surpassed by the Bible and the works of William Shakespeare. Her estate claims that three billion copies have been sold. According to the Guinness World Records, Christie's works come third in the list of best-selling books, behind only Shakespeare and the Bible. She is the only British crime writer to have been given officer rank in the French military: in 1919 she was made a Commander of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres for her contribution to the arts of France. She has been called the "Queen of Crime", a title bestowed by the Academy of Crime as a lifetime achievement award for someone who has contributed to the field of crime literature. Her first novel, the Belgian expatriate tale The Mysterious Affair at Styles, was published in 1920. Two years later, The Blue Book magazine published a list of the best 100 books since 1920, with The Murder of Roger Ackroyd placed at no. 39 and And Then There Were None at no. 77 on the list, marking the enduring appeal of Agatha Christie's novels. She is credited with making detective and crime stories accessible to a wide audience, particularly with books such as The Mysterious Affair at Styles. She was successful because, unlike Edgar Allan Poe, she did not create stories about evil geniuses – instead she used "regular" people to solve the crimes. Christie's works are known for baffling mysteries, high-functioning detectives, complex plots, twist endings, and intriguing characters. According to literary historian G. K. Hall, her works are often at their best when she is employing all of these elements to play off against one another. She also used these narrative devices to subvert the genre's standards and expectations. She also uses the narrative device of allowing the first-person narrator, who is one of the main suspects, to
facts: reveal the truth at the end of the story. Agatha Christie's books have been adapted into numerous films, television series, and stage plays, including the long-running play The Mousetrap, which is the longest continuously running play in history. Christie's most famous fictional detective is Hercule Poirot, a Belgian detective known for his intellect and meticulous attention to detail. Poirot appeared in 33 novels, one play, and more than 50 short stories. Another popular character created by Christie is Miss Marple, an elderly spinster who solves crimes in her small village. Miss Marple appeared in 12 novels and 20 short stories. Christie's works have had a significant impact on the crime genre and continue to be enjoyed by readers around the world.

bio: Fight Club is a 1996 novel by American author Chuck Palahniuk. It follows the experiences of an unnamed protagonist struggling with insomnia. Inspired by his doctor's exasperated remark that insomnia is not suffering, the protagonist finds relief by impersonating a seriously ill person in several support groups. Then he meets a mysterious man named Tyler Durden and establishes an underground fighting club as radical psychotherapy. The narrator and Tyler rebel against their mundane lives. They set out on a cross-country spree, attacking symbols of consumerism and other "artificial hierarchies".

bio: Corey Taylor (born Corey James M. DeVille; November 8, 1980) is the lead vocalist, lyricist and songwriter for American heavy metal bands Slipknot and Stone Sour. Taylor began his career as the lead vocalist for Slipknot in 1996, but due to his alcoholism, was fired from the band in 2000. With the help of Stone Sour frontman Jim Root, Taylor remained sober. In 2004, Stone Sour secured a record deal and went on to tour with Slipknot, where he became its vocalist upon the dismissal of its previous frontman, Anders Colsefini. Stone Sour has released five albums: Stone Sour (2002), Come What(ever) May (2006), Audio Secrecy (2010), House of Gold & Bones – Part 1 (2012), and House of Gold & Bones – Part 2 (2013). Their 2006 album, Come What(ever) May, peaked at number 4 in the US Billboard 200 charts. All five of Stone Sour's albums received Gold certification by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA), while the first three albums have been certified Platinum.

bio: Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 film and the second part of the Back to the Future trilogy. It is the sequel to Back to the Future and was the second highest grossing film of 1989, earning over $331 million worldwide. It was released on November 22, 1989. The story takes place immediately after the first film on July 3, 1985; however, unlike its predecessor it begins in 2015. The three leads are Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Crispin Glover and Claudia Wells (in special make-up); Mary Steenburgen and Elisabeth Shue play Marty's girlfriend, Jennifer. The film also stars James Tolkan, Jason Scott Lee, and Thomas F. Wilson.

bio: The Matrix Revolutions is a 2003 American science fiction action film written and directed by The Wachowskis. It is the third installment of The Matrix trilogy, following The Matrix (1999) and The Matrix Reloaded (2003). The film was produced by Andy Wachowski, Larry Wachowski, and Bruce Berman. It was released 6 November 2003 in Australia, 14 November in North America, and 19 November in the United Kingdom, Ireland and most parts of the world. Six months after the events of The Matrix Reloaded, with the machines working to exterminate Zion's Elder Council, Neo, Morpheus and Trinity attempt to reason with the Council.

bio: Charles Marie de La Condamine (4 February 1701 – 4 February 1774) was a French mathematician and geographer. He participated in an 18th-century scientific expedition to Ecuador led by Spanish Ruy de Villalobos, to measure the shape of the Earth. He is most famous for leading an expedition to Peru with two companions, and making the first measurements there of a meridian (a north–south line of longitude) at the equator, from Quito to the River Amazon, which established the fact that the length of a degree of longitude at the equator is greater than at higher latitudes.

bio: Solange Knowles (born June 24, 1986) is an American singer, songwriter, model and actress. Born and raised in Houston, Texas, she was raised in a musically oriented family; her father Mathew Knowles manages Destiny's Child, while her mother Tina Knowles designs their fashion. At age five, Solange met music producer and rapper MC Hammer, and made her first appearance on his 1997 album, Too Legit to Quit. Knowles moved to the East Coast with her family, including her then 16-year-old sister Beyoncé. After auditioning unsuccessfully for American Idol, she returned to her hometown, and was briefly signed to a joint venture between Capitol Records and her father's Music World Entertainment, but was later dropped.

bio: Edgar Allan Poe (; January 19, 1809 - October 7, 1849) was an American writer, editor, and literary critic. Poe is best known for his poetry and short stories, particularly his tales of mystery and the macabre. He is widely regarded as a central figure of Romanticism in the United States and American literature as a whole, and he was one of the country's earliest practitioners of the short story. He is generally considered the inventor of the detective fiction genre and is further credited with contributing to the emerging genre of science fiction. He was the first well-known American writer to try to earn a living through writing alone, resulting in a financially difficult life and career.

bio: Northeast megalopolis is a region roughly bounded by the Catskill Mountains, the southern part of New Hampshire, the northern part of North Carolina, the Atlantic Ocean, and the Ohio River. According to Robert Lang of the Metropolitan Institute at Virginia Tech, the region is one of the largest urban areas in the world. The population of the region is 53.5 million.

bio: Transformers: Dark of the Moon is a 2011 American science fiction action film directed by Michael Bay and based on the toy line of the same name created by Hasbro. It is part of the live-action Transformers film series and is the third installment of the series, following Transformers and Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen. The film was co-written by Ehren Kruger and produced by Steven Spielberg, co-produced by Tom DeSanto, and executive produced by Don Murphy. Bay returned as director, with stars Shia LaBeouf and Josh Duhamel reprising their roles. It also features Rosie Huntington-Whiteley as Shia LaBeouf's on-screen replacement. The film's voice cast includes Peter Cullen, who portrays the voice of Optimus Prime, and John Turturro, who voices Seymour.

bio: Transformers: Age of Extinction is a 2014 American science fiction action film based on the Transformers toy line. It is the fourth and final installment of the live-action Transformers film series. It was directed by Michael Bay and written by Ehren Kruger, and stars Mark Wahlberg, Stanley Tucci, Kelsey Grammer, Nicola Peltz, Jack Reynor, Sophia Myles, Li Bingbing, and Titus Welliver. It was executive produced by Steven Spielberg, Bay, and Lorenzo di Bonaventura, with Brian Goldner, Mark Vahradian and Bradley Fuller as producers. In the film, a group of Autobots and humans search for the inventor of the Transformers, while attempting to stay hidden from the U. S. military.

bio: Lumen Pierce is a fictional character in the third series of Life is Strange, an episodic graphic adventure game by Dontnod Entertainment and published by Square Enix. He is the protagonist of Minus, a side character in Sphere, and has a minor role in Awake, and is a major character in the finale, Dust and in Before the Storm, both with his sister and Rachel Amber. He is also the protagonist and player controlled character in Before the Storm. Lumen is the son of James and Cassandra Pierce and the younger brother of Maxine "Max" Caulfield, the protagonist of the Life Is Strange series. Lumen Pierce is voiced by Austin Film Works.

bio: Soundgarden is an American rock band formed in Seattle, Washington, in 1984 by singer Chris Cornell and guitarist Kim Thayil. With them, Cornell and Thayil began recording what would become the band's debut album, Ultramega OK, released in 1988 by local independent record label Sub Pop. Soundgarden's current lineup comprises Cornell, Thayil, and bassist Ben Shepherd, who replaced the departed Hiro Yamamoto in 1990. Since Ultramega OK, Soundgarden has won two Grammy Awards, and achieved two platinum and three multi-platinum albums; the band has sold more than 11 million records in the U.S., including 2 million albums sales in 2010 and 1 million albums sales in 2011 (two of the band's records were released in 2010 and 2011).

bio: Bob Arum, sometimes known as Robert J. Arum, (born Robert Aaron Arum 1 April 1931), is an American lawyer and boxing promoter. He began his career in boxing in 1967 before forming his own company, Top Rank, Inc. in 1983. In 2004 he became the exclusive boxing promoter for USA Network.

bio: Josh Duhamel (; born November 14, 1972) is an American actor and film producer. He first achieved acting success in 1999 as Leo du Pres on ABC's All My Children and later as Mike on NBC's Las Vegas. He is also known for his role as Captain William Lennox in the 2007 live-action/CGI film Transformers and its sequels. Since 2014, he has starred as Danny Burton on the CBS sitcom Battle Creek.

bio: Basic Instinct is a 1992 American psychological erotic thriller film written and directed by Paul Verhoeven and produced by Howard G. Kazanjian. It stars Michael Douglas, Sharon Stone, and Jeanne Tripplehorn. The film revolves around a police detective, played by Douglas, who begins an intense cat-and-mouse relationship with an unstable, self-destructive novelist, played by Stone, who may have committed a series of murders. It is based on Joe Eszterhas's screenplay, loosely adapting his 1991 novel of the same name, which was a bestseller at the time.

bio: Plato was an Athenian philosopher during the Classical period in Ancient Greece, founder of the Platonist school of thought, writer of philosophical works and teacher of Aristotle, founder of the Peripatetic school. Plato's informal conversations (Socratic dialogues) recorded in writing by his student, Plato, had significant influence on Western philosophy. Plato (428/427 – 347/348 B.C.) is considered by many as the greatest philosopher of all time and the most influential figure in philosophy of the Western world (he coined the term 'philosophy' as we know it today). Through his teacher Socrates, Plato examined the essence of knowledge, or the 'good', and the implications of this quest. Plato wrote that the fundamental problem in philosophy is to determine the 'true' nature of reality, the true form of 'the good' and 'the beautiful', and it was in attempting to do this that he became one of the first philosophers to distinguish between appearance and reality. He also coined many terms known today, including 'eidos' and 'amorphos'.

bio: Johnny Mnemonic (film) is a 1995 Canadian-American cyberpunk science fiction action-thriller film directed by Robert Longo and written by William Gibson and Michael Almereyda. Gibson's script is based on his short story and was developed by Longo who collaborated with Gibson during the writing process. The film stars Keanu Reeves, Dolph Lundgren, Dina Meyer, Ice-T and Udo Kier. It explores the concepts of information overload and human augmentation, especially with respect to the cybernetic brain implants depicted in the film, which have been criticised for their plausibility.

bio: Daniel Craig (born 2 March 1968) is an English actor. In 2005, he landed the role of James Bond and starred in Casino Royale and Quantum of Solace, two of the highest-grossing James Bond films; in 2012, he starred in the seventh-highest-grossing film of all time, Skyfall, for which he won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor nomination. He also starred as Ian Fleming in the television film Fleming (2014). He has been in the films Road to Perdition (2002), Elizabeth (1998), The Golden Compass (2007), Defiance (2008), Cowboys & Aliens (2011), and The Adventures of Tintin (2011). For his role as Bond in Casino Royale, Craig received a BAFTA award, a Golden Globe and a Satellite Award.

bio: Purple Haze is the third studio album by Jimi Hendrix, released in 1967 by record label Track Records UK & Reprise Records USA. The album was produced by Chas Chandler, who was the bassist of the Animals and Hendrix's manager at the time. It is an entirely instrumental album which differs from his previous releases and was recorded without a band line-up.

bio: Nikita (TV series) (French: Nikita) is a Canadian TV series which is an adaptation of Luc Besson's film of the same name. It is produced by Hypnotic and distributor Sony Pictures Television (SPT) and was developed by Craig Silverstein for the U.S. networks NBC and The CW. Nikita was ordered to series with a 13 episode order by The CW on May 19, 2010 and premiered October 1, 2010. The CW moved its premiere date because of a presidential debate. The first season was ordered by The CW on November 18, 2010, with the addition of an 18th episode, and the pick up was made official on February 15, 2011. The series has undergone some cast changes in the second season that began on September 21, 2011.

bio: Republic of Ireland, also known as Eire and Ireland, is a parliamentary republic in North-Western Europe occupying five-sixths of the island of Ireland. The Republic of Ireland is a member of the European Union and is a developed country with an average GDP per capita of € 29,617. The roots of Irish nationalism, republicanism, and independence lie in the 19th century Irish Rebellion of 1798, which was the beginning of a campaign for independence. From 1801 until the early 20th century, large portions of Ireland remained part of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, which led to a growing Irish independence movement. After over a century of campaigning for various kinds of Home Rule within Ireland, Irish republicans seized upon the Easter Uprising in Dublin in 1916 to seize political and military control of 26 of Ireland's 32 counties and to proclaim the Irish Republic. This came to an end when it was suppressed by British forces by the end of the month. During 1918-21, British forces intervened on numerous occasions in an attempt to crush the Republic of Ireland, but they failed to achieve that goal. In 1921-22, the Anglo-Irish Treaty established the Irish Free State and Northern Ireland in place of the United Kingdom's jurisdiction in most of Ireland.
